subject: Paper on deriving unit tests from functional tests

messageBody:
All,

David Saff introduced me to a technique a couple of weeks ago that I'd like
to share. So you have a defect and a system-level test that fails. How do
you find the line(s) of code you need to change? The traditional (defined as
"what I used to do") way is to single step in a debugger. Once I find the
defect, though, I only have the system test's word that I've fixed it.

The Saff Squeeze is an alternative way to find the defect. You inline the
offending method call in the system test. Then you move the assertion to
somewhere in the middle of the inlined code. Then you prune the
now-irrelevant parts of the test. Repeat until you can't inline further
without losing sight of the incorrect code. By running tests as you go along
you get concrete feedback about your hypothesis regarding what's wrong. The
resulting test isolates the problem and provide a nice complementary
regression test to the original test. That's why I titled the paper "Hit 'Em
High, Hit 'Em Low" www.threeriversinstitute.org/HitEmHighHitEmLow.html.

If you try the Squeeze I'd like to hear how it goes.

Cheers,

Kent
